choices.text: < 30% of the calories should come from fat

questions.text: A diabetic patient's fasting blood glucose level is found to be 160 mg/dL. What will you advise the patient regarding non-pharmacological management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) <30% of the calories should come from Fat

 

In diabetic patients, dietary modification is an essential part of management. Limiting fat intake to less than 30% of total calories helps reduce insulin resistance, prevent dyslipidemia, and decrease cardiovascular risk, which is high in diabetics. Within this, saturated fat should be kept below 10% of total calories, and trans fats should be avoided. Emphasis is placed on complex carbohydrates, high-fiber foods, and weight control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At least 80g dietary fibre: This amount is excessive and not practical. The recommended daily intake of fiber for diabetics is about 25–40 g, which helps improve glycemic control and lipid profile.

 

Option B. <8 g salt intake everyday: This recommendation is more relevant to hypertension and cardiovascular risk reduction, not specifically to glycemic control. However, diabetics with hypertension are advised to limit salt to <5 g/day.

 

Option D. Cholesterol <100g: This is incorrect because cholesterol intake is measured in milligrams, not grams. The actual recommendation is dietary cholesterol intake <300 mg/day (and even lower, <200 mg, in diabetics with cardiovascular disease).

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is not an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/OTs

 

Under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), cataract surgeries are performed in well-equipped fixed facilities to ensure sterility, safety, and better outcomes. Performing surgeries in makeshift hospitals or temporary rural OTs is not recommended because of poor infrastructure, risk of infection, and lack of postoperative care. Instead, patients from rural areas are transported to base hospitals or permanent facilities for surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This is correct. Identification and referral of eligible cataract patients to base hospitals is a key component of the program to ensure organized and safe surgical care.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery: This is accurate. The program emphasizes small incision cataract surgery (SICS) over traditional extracapsular extraction due to its safety, cost-effectiveness, and quicker rehabilitation.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This is correct. Patients are transported from rural areas to fixed facilities with proper operating theaters to maintain standards of sterility and care

choices.text: The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase
NPU is the best for protein quality
Standardisation is done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries due to difference in number of deaths
Perflation ventilation is a type of mechanical ventilation

questions.text: Identify the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase

 

Annual Parasite Incidence (API) is an important epidemiological indicator for malaria. According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016–2030), a state can be considered in the elimination phase if the API is less than 1 and all districts within that state also report API <1. This ensures transmission is uniformly controlled and not just limited to selected areas. Achieving and maintaining API <1 across all districts is a prerequisite before declaring malaria elimination status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NPU is the best for protein quality: This is incorrect. Biological Value (BV) is considered the best index for protein quality, not Net Protein Utilization (NPU). BV measures how efficiently dietary protein is converted into body proteins. Biological Value = [retained Nitrogen/Absorbed nitrogen] x 100

 

Option C. Standardisation is done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries due to difference in number of deaths: Wrong because standardization corrects for differences in age structure of populations, not just the number of deaths. Crude mortality rates may be misleading if age distributions differ.

 

Option D. Perflation ventilation is a type of mechanical ventilation: Incorrect. There is no such type of ventilation called perflation ventilation. Recognized types include volume-controlled, pressure-controlled, high-frequency, etc. This option is a distractor.

choices.text: Seal cracks and close all windows and doors

questions.text: A city experiences a chemical plant leak and toxic fumes are released into the atmosphere. What is your immediate recommendation to the local residents?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seal cracks and close all windows and doors

 

When airborne toxic fumes are released, the immediate safest action for people inside buildings is to “shelter in place” — close and seal windows and doors and block gaps to reduce infiltration of contaminated air. This minimizes exposure until authorities give further instructions (evacuation or decontamination). Evacuation can be dangerous if done without directions because residents might move into contaminated zones. After sealing, people should switch off ventilation/AC that brings outside air and listen to official updates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Telephone to inform friends: Calling friends is not the immediate protective action — it wastes time and may expose the caller while delaying sheltering. Priority is to reduce exposure first; communication can follow once safely sheltered or via emergency broadcasts.

 

Option B. Evacuate immediately: Immediate evacuation is risky unless there is clear direction from authorities; residents may move into contaminated plumes or traffic gridlock. Evacuation is done only when officials instruct and provide safe routes and destinations.

 

Option C. Open windows for ventilation: Opening windows increases indoor contamination by allowing toxic fumes to enter — this is the opposite of what should be done during a chemical leak. Only ventilate when authorities confirm the area is safe.

questions.text: The World Health Organization suggests the use of a new rapid diagnostic test for the diagnosis of malaria in resource-limited settings. The new test has a sensitivity of 70% and a specificity of 90% compared to the gold standard test (blood smear). The validity of the new test is evaluated at a satellite health center by testing 200 patients with a positive blood smear and 150 patients with a negative blood smear. How many of the tested individuals are expected to have a false negative result?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60

 

False negatives occur among those who truly have malaria (blood-smear positive) and are missed by the test. 

 

Sensitivity = 70% means the test correctly identifies 70% of true positives and misses 30%.

 

Remember the formulae:

 

Here,

 

For 200 true positives, 30% × 200 = 60 false negatives. So 60 individuals with positive blood smears will test negative on the rapid test.

choices.text: National Nutritional Deficiency and Control Programme

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presented to the PHC with difficulty in walking and bowing of legs. She was undernourished and had minimal exposure to the sun. Which programme deals with nutritional deficiency in children below 6 years of age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Integrated Child Development Services

 

ICDS is the primary national programme for early childhood care and nutrition, targeting children 0–6 years through anganwadi centres. It provides supplementary nutrition, growth monitoring, immunisation linkages, and health/nutrition education — all aimed at preventing and treating undernutrition and deficiency disorders in this age group. Management of rickets-related nutritional problems (vitamin D/calcium and overall malnutrition) falls within ICDS scope via supplementation and referral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaemia Mukt Bharat: This programme specifically targets anaemia across age groups with iron-folic acid supplementation and screening but is not the comprehensive programme for all nutritional deficiencies in 0–6-year-olds.

 

Option C. National Nutritional Deficiency and Control Programme: This older/less commonly referenced programme name is not the primary current delivery platform for under-6 nutrition; ICDS is the operational programme for this age group.

 

Option D. Mid-Day Meal Scheme: Mid-Day Meals target school-age children (usually 6–14 years) to improve nutrition and attendance — they do not cover children below 6 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an organophosphate insecticide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DDT

 

DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is an organochlorine insecticide, not an organophosphate. Organophosphates (like fenthion, malathion, diazinon) act by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase; DDT works via prolonged sodium channel activation and has different chemical class and toxicological profile. DDT is historically used in vector control but is distinct chemically and in regulatory considerations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fenthion: Fenthion is an organophosphate insecticide that inhibits acetylcholinesterase and is used for agricultural and vector control; it belongs to the correct class.

 

Option C. Malathion: Malathion is a widely used organophosphate insecticide/larvicide and acts by cholinesterase inhibition — it is correctly an organophosphate.

 

Option D. Diazinon: Diazinon is also an organophosphate insecticide with acetylcholinesterase-inhibiting action — thus not the odd one out.

questions.text: A city has 70,00,000 urban population, 30% of which live in slums. How many UPHCs are required for the slum population according to NUHM norms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 42

 

Slum population = 7,000,000 × 30% = 2,100,000. 

 

NUHM/UPHC planning uses a norm of roughly 1 UPHC per 50,000 urban population (guidelines often quote 50,000–60,000; quality standards note UPHCs cater to ~25–30k slum population locally but programmatic norm for planning commonly uses 50,000).

 

Using the standard 1 per 50,000: 2,100,000 ÷ 50,000 = 42 UPHCs required to cover the slum population.

questions.text: The central value of a sample of 200 observations can be obtained by calculating which measure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2nd quartile 

 

The 2nd quartile is the median, which divides an ordered dataset into two equal halves and represents the central value. For any sample (including 200 observations), the median gives the central tendency less sensitive to extreme values than the mean. Quartiles split data into four equal parts; the second (Q2) corresponds to the 50th percentile (median).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 90th percentile: The 90th percentile marks the value below which 90% of observations fall — it is a high-end measure, not the central value.

 

Option B. 2nd decile: The 2nd decile is the 20th percentile (value below which 20% of observations lie) — not the central measure.

 

Option C. Interquartile range: IQR is a measure of spread (Q3 − Q1), not a central value; it describes variability between the first and third quartiles.

choices.text: Higher sensitivity and the same specificity

questions.text: A standard test based on a serum marker is used to diagnose disease X. The distribution of the marker for this standard test in healthy and diseased patients is shown by the red curves in the graph below. A competitive company developed a new test based on the same marker. The distribution of the marker for the new test in healthy and diseased patients is shown by the black curves in the graph below. Compared to the old test, the new test has?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Higher sensitivity and higher specificity

 

Compared to the old test, the new test has higher sensitivity and higher specificity.

 

  • The black curves (new test) for healthy and diseased subjects are narrower and further separated, reducing overlap compared to the red curves (old test).
  • This means the ability to correctly identify both healthy (specificity) and diseased (sensitivity) individuals is improved because the marker levels are less likely to be misclassified.

  • Narrow distributions and greater separation increase the test's 

    discriminative power for both conditions

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about hospice care? 

 

A. Disease is the centre of concern 

B. The patient is sovereign 

C. Death should neither be prolonged nor hastened 

D. The aim is to improve the quality of life 

E. The intention is to cure 

F. Done when expected survival is <6months
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B, C, D, F.

 

Statement B. The patient is sovereign: Correct. Patient autonomy is respected.

 

Statement C. Death should neither be prolonged nor hastened: Correct. Hospice supports a natural death process.

 

Statement D. The aim is to improve the quality of life: Correct. Main focus is comfort and dignity.

 

Statement F. Done when expected survival is <6 months: Correct. Typically eligibility is prognosis ≤6 months (if illness runs its natural course).

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement A. Disease is the centre of concern: Incorrect. In hospice, patient and family are the focus, not the disease.

 

Statement E. The intention is to cure: Incorrect. Hospice is palliative, not curative.

questions.text: In the context of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, which of the following factors does not affect the genetic equilibrium of a population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Random mating

 

  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium assumes that certain conditions are met for a population to maintain genetic stability. 
  • These conditions include no mutations, no migration, a large population size, random mating, and no natural selection. 
  • Random mating does not disrupt equilibrium; in fact, it is one of the assumptions of the Hardy-Weinberg model. 
  • However, factors such as small population size (leading to genetic drift), mutations, and gene outflow (migration) can disrupt the equilibrium and change allele frequencies in a population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small population: A small population violates the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium by increasing the effects of genetic drift, which can cause random changes in allele frequencies, leading to a departure from equilibrium.

 

Option C. Mutations: Mutations introduce new genetic variations and can alter allele frequencies, thus disrupting Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

 

Option D. Gene outflow: Gene outflow, or migration (the movement of individuals or their genetic material into or out of a population), alters allele frequencies by introducing or removing genes, disrupting equilibrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Random mating is a condition required for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, and does not affect genetic equilibrium, unlike factors such as small population size, mutations, and gene outflow.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with T2DM presents with high grade fever and cough. He is diagnosed with COVID-19 and is admitted. He dies on the 7th day of illness. As part of surveillance, his death is recorded. What type of surveillance is this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Passive

 

Passive surveillance relies on routine, ongoing reporting of health events (e.g., deaths) by healthcare facilities to public health authorities without active case seeking by investigators. The hospital recording the death and reporting it fits passive surveillance. Active surveillance would involve public health teams actively searching for cases; sentinel involves selected reporting sites; syndromic focuses on symptom patterns rather than confirmed deaths.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active: Active surveillance requires proactive case-finding by health staff (e.g., visits, calls) — not just routine death recording by the admitting hospital.

 

Option C. Sentinel: Sentinel surveillance uses selected sites to monitor trends; while hospitals can be sentinel sites, a routine death report from an admitting site is standard passive reporting unless the site is part of a sentinel network.

 

Option D. Syndromic: Syndromic surveillance tracks symptom clusters (e.g., ILI) prior to diagnosis; recording a confirmed death is not syndromic surveillance.

choices.text: Village Health Planning and Management Committee
Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

questions.text: As part of a health development project in rural India, you're asked about the key community group responsible for overseeing local health, sanitation, and nutrition initiatives. Which committee best fits this description?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

 

VHSNCs are the community-level  platforms specifically mandated to oversee health, sanitation, nutrition, and related determinants at the village/ward level. They bring together ASHAs, ANMs, PRI members and community representatives to plan local health actions, monitor services, and ensure convergence of nutrition and sanitation efforts. Rogi Kalyan Samitis and Panchayat Health Committees have roles but VHSNC is the focused community committee for these grassroots activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panchayat Health Committee: Panchayat committees may address broader local governance and health issues but VHSNCs are the designated village-level health-sanitation-nutrition bodies.

 

Option B. Village Health Planning and Management Committee: This name is not the standard, widely used community forum under NRHM/NUHM/ICDS; VHSNC is the specific recognized structure.

 

Option C. Rogi Kalyan Samiti: RKS (Rogi Kalyan Samiti) functions at facility level (hospital/PHC) for facility management and user participation, not primarily for village-level sanitation/nutrition oversight.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of an interview in the correct order in a sequence.

 

1. Starting an interview

2. Encouragement

3. Establishing contact

4. Securing rapport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-4-2

 

First establish contact (3) — initial greeting and introductions — which opens the interaction. 

 

 

Then start the interview (1) by stating purpose and agenda. 

 

 

Next secure rapport (4) through empathy, appropriate nonverbal cues, and trust-building.

 

 

Finally provide encouragement (2) during the interview to elicit information and maintain dialogue.

 

This sequence supports a logical, patient-centred interview flow.

questions.text: A new community-based initiative is designed to reduce neonatal sepsis. In a community, 20 randomly assigned PHCs follow standard care and 20 are designated to implement the new initiative. What type of study design is this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cluster randomised controlled trial

 

PHCs (health centres) are randomized as units (clusters) to intervention or control — that is a cluster randomized controlled trial. Randomization at cluster level avoids contamination between individuals within the same PHC. Quasi-experimental designs lack random assignment; case-control and cross-sectional designs have different structures and do not randomize clusters prospectively like this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quasi-experimental study: Quasi-experimental implies non-random assignment of groups — here the PHCs are randomly assigned, so this is not quasi-experimental.

 

Option C. Case-control study: Case-control studies compare exposures retrospectively between cases and controls, not randomize clusters to interventions prospectively.

 

Option D. Cross-sectional study: Cross-sectional studies measure exposure and outcome at a single time point and do not involve randomized assignment of interventions.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about vaccines

  1. Influenza and yellow fever vaccines are CI in egg allergy

  2. Abscess formation post-BCG is treated conservatively

  3. Live vaccines should not be given with Human immunoglobulin except measles

  4. All of the following are killed vaccines: Pertussis, Salk, SA14-14-2, 17D

  5. NS is used as diluent for Danish 1331
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,5

 

1. Influenza and yellow fever vaccines are CI in egg allergy: Correct. Both are prepared in egg medium; severe egg allergy is a contraindication.

 

2. Abscess formation post-BCG is treated conservatively: Incorrect. Cold abscess after BCG is aspirated, not left alone.

 

3. Live vaccines should not be given with Human immunoglobulin except measles: Incorrect. Exception is tetanus and Hep B

 

4. All of the following are killed vaccines: Pertussis, Salk, SA14-14-2, 17D → Incorrect.

 

  • Pertussis (killed, whole cell) 
  • Salk (inactivated polio) 
  • SA14-14-2 (Japanese encephalitis live attenuated) 
  • 17D (Yellow fever live attenuated) 

 

5. NS is used as diluent for Danish 1331 (BCG strain): Correct. So, the correct statements = 1 and 5 only.

choices.text: Location at the time of enumeration

questions.text: In ‘De facto’ method of census data collection, information is collected based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Location at the time of enumeration

 

In the De facto method of census:

 

  • Information is collected from people where they are physically present at the time of enumeration, regardless of their usual residence or place of birth.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Place of birth: Place of birth is demographic information, but enumeration is not based on it.

 

Option B. Place of employment: People may work in one area and live in another; census is not based on workplace.

 

Option C. Usual place of residence: That is the De jure method, where people are counted at their normal/official residence, even if they are away at the time.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of steps in investigating an epidemic?

 

1. Confirm epidemic existence

2. Verify the diagnosis

3. Formulation of hypothesis

4. Define the population at risk

5. Rapid search of cases
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2 → 1 → 4 → 5 → 3

 

Explanation of sequence:

 

1. Verify the diagnosis: Ensure clinical and lab confirmation to avoid misclassification.

 

2. Confirm epidemic existence: Establish that cases exceed expected baseline; rules out false alarm.

 

4. Define the population at risk: Finally, identify the community/group most vulnerable to guide control measures

 

5. Rapid search of cases: Case finding through active surveillance to measure extent of spread.

 

3. Formulation of hypothesis: Develop tentative explanation for source, mode, and risk factors.

questions.text: In the context of the World Health Organization's International Health Regulations (IHR), "immediately notifiable diseases" refer to specific diseases that must be reported to the WHO. What is the time period to report them and the diseases included in the list? Identify the correct pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 24 hrs, SARS

 

  • Immediately notifiable diseases under IHR (2005):
    • Smallpox
    • Poliomyelitis due to wild poliovirus
    • Human influenza caused by a new subtype
    • Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)
  • Time limit: These must be notified to WHO within 24 hours of assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a vital statistic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dependency ratio

 

Not a vital statistic. It is a demographic measure (ratio of dependents <15 and >64 years to working-age population 15–64 years).

P= population of respective age in brackets mentioned

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Vital statistic. Derived from registered live births in a given population and time.

 

Option B. Fertility rate: Vital statistic. Measures reproductive performance in a population.

 

Option D. Life expectancy at birth: Vital statistic. Derived from mortality data and life tables.

questions.text: A researcher studies the incidence of measles in a population of 100 children, where 10 children have a previous history of measles, and 20 have been affected by the disease for the first time. What is the incidence?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22.22%

 

The incidence of a disease is defined as the proportion of new cases in the population at risk over a specified period.

 

Calculation

 

  • Population at risk: 90 children
  • Already had measles: 10 (these are NOT at risk for first-time infection)
  • New cases (first episode): 20

 

Incidence= Number of new cases/Population at risk 

 

Here,  20/90=0.22=22.22%

questions.text: Researchers develop a new test to detect the presence of a recently identified biomarker NMP22 for ca UB. The initial evaluation of the test shows the following. Which of the following is the likelihood that a patient with a negative test does not have ca UB?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.96

 

The likelihood that a patient with a negative test does not have ca UB is the Negative Predictive Value (NPV).

 

Calculation of Negative Predictive Value (NPV)

 

  • NPV=                   True Negatives 
  • From the table:
    • True Negatives (Test negative, Disease not present) = 120
    • False Negatives (Test negative, Disease present) = 5
    • Total negatives = 120 + 5 = 125

            (True Negatives + False Negatives)

 

NPV=120/120+5=120/125=0.96

questions.text:
The target demographic for latest RMNCAH+N includes which of the following?


a. Maternal and child health
b. Family planning services
c. Geriatric health
d. Adolescent health
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, b and d

 

The latest RMNCAH+N (Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, Adolescent Health + Nutrition) target demographic includes maternal and child health, family planning services, and adolescent health. Geriatric health is not part of this strategy.

 

RMNCAH+N addresses reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, adolescent health, and nutrition, focusing on the lifecycle approach from pre-pregnancy to adolescence but excluding elderly or geriatric health.

 

Family planning services are integral to reproductive health services covered.

 

Adolescent health is explicitly included in RMNCAH+N frameworks

questions.text: Knowledge, Attitude, and Practice (KAP) studies were first introduced in India for studying:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Family planning

 

  • KAP surveys were pioneered in India during family planning programs to measure population knowledge, attitudes, and actual practices regarding contraception. These helped shape strategies for acceptance of birth control.
  • KAP stands for Knowledge, Attitude, and Practice study/survey.
  • It is a structured survey tool used to assess what people know (Knowledge), how they feel (Attitude), and how they behave (Practice) towards a specific topic, often health-related.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV: KAP studies became important later in HIV/AIDS programs to assess awareness, risk perception, and preventive behaviour, but this was not their first use in India.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: KAP surveys are used today for lifestyle diseases like diabetes to assess diet and compliance, but they were not the earliest application.

 

Option D. Malaria: Surveys for malaria focused mainly on prevalence and treatment-seeking behaviour; KAP methodology was not first applied here.

choices.text: To confirm individual diagnoses with additional tests
For immediate quarantine of symptomatic individuals
To detect warning signs of disease outbreak

questions.text: During the Mahakumbh mela, the government set up health care camps and mobile medical units for surveillance. A syndromic surveillance is done for fever, diarrhoea and respiratory symptoms. What is the primary reason to do this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To detect warning signs of disease outbreak

 

Syndromic surveillance is mainly designed for early detection of unusual patterns that could signal an outbreak. It focuses on symptoms rather than confirmed diagnoses, allowing public health authorities to intervene rapidly before a disease spreads widely.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To confirm individual diagnoses with additional tests: INCORRECT. Syndromic surveillance is not for confirming individual cases; it is a rapid tool to track trends. Laboratory tests are needed for confirmation.

 

Option B. To reduce the medical personnel: INCORRECT. The system may simplify reporting but is not meant to cut staff. In fact, mass gatherings often need more personnel.

 

Option C. For immediate quarantine of symptomatic individuals: INCORRECT. Quarantine is based on confirmed or highly suspected communicable diseases, not just on syndromic data.

choices.text: Detection of VDPV in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of a single case of wild polio in a person with Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of any cVDPV infected individuals
Detection of wild PV infection in a healthy asymptomatic individual

questions.text: Any of the following should be considered as evidence of an outbreak of polio except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Detection of VDPV in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis 

 

  • Outbreak definition (WHO/India Polio Eradication Initiative):
    • A single case of wild poliovirus (WPV) in an AFP patient = outbreak.
    • Any detection of cVDPV (circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus) = outbreak.
    • Detection of WPV in a healthy individual (via contact/environmental surveillance) is also treated as outbreak evidence, because it indicates community circulation.
  • But detection of VDPV (Vaccine Derived Poliovirus, non-circulating, in a single AFP case) is not always considered an outbreak. It may be an isolated case, not yet evidence of circulation. Only when it is cVDPV (circulating, genetically linked in multiple cases or environmental isolates) does it constitute an outbreak.

choices.text: Symptomatic treatment of cases with NSAIDs and isolation
Purified, inactivated FDA approved vaccine is found to be helpful in prevention
Sexual abstinence, using condoms, delaying pregnancy is helpful in controlling the disease
Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis is used in the treatment of Zika

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to the prevention of Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sexual abstinence, using condoms, delaying pregnancy is helpful in controlling the disease

 

Preventive measures include avoiding mosquito bites, practicing safe sex, and delaying pregnancy in outbreak settings due to the risk of congenital anomalies. These are WHO-recommended strategies for prevention in the absence of a vaccine.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symptomatic treatment of cases with NSAIDs and isolation: NSAIDs are avoided initially due to risk of bleeding (differentiation from dengue needed). Isolation alone is not sufficient for prevention.

 

Option B. Purified, inactivated FDA approved vaccine is found to be helpful in prevention: No licensed vaccine is available yet for Zika virus; vaccines are still under trial.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis is used in the treatment of Zika: Not used for Zika itself; plasmapheresis may be applied only if Zika leads to Guillain–Barré syndrome as a complication.

questions.text: A new biomarker has been shown to allow for the early detection of non-small cell lung carcinoma. A preliminary analysis on a cohort study of this new test demonstrates that its use prolongs survival of lung cancer patients by 3 months when compared to the survival of patients diagnosed by conventional methods. A secondary analysis reveals no difference in 6-month mortality rates between the 2 groups. Which of the following factors most likely explains the study results?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lead-time bias

 

Lead-time bias occurs when earlier detection of a disease (by screening or new tests) falsely appears to improve survival, even though the actual course and outcome of the disease are unchanged. The extra "time lived" is only due to earlier diagnosis, not better prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confounding: Occurs when an external variable distorts the true association between exposure and outcome. Here, both groups had the same disease and mortality, so confounding is unlikely.

 

Option C. Length-time bias: Happens when screening disproportionately detects slower-progressing, less aggressive cases, giving an impression of better survival. Not the case here since both groups had similar mortality.

 

Option D. Measurement bias: Arises from systematic error in data collection (eg- faulty instruments, poor classification). The test detected cancer earlier, not incorrectly.

questions.text: For calculating the life expectancy index in Human Development Index (HDI), what are the minimum and maximum values used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 years and 85 years

 

UNDP sets 20 years as the minimum and 85 years as the maximum benchmarks for life expectancy in HDI calculations.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) World TB Day – 24 April

 

  • World TB Day is actually observed on 24 March, not 24 April.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. World Health Day – 7 April: Correct, marks the founding of WHO in 1948.

 

Option C. World Population Day – 11 July: Correct, observed annually since 1989.

 

Option D. World AIDS Day – 1 December: Correct, commemorates the global fight against HIV/AIDS.

questions.text: Which health program in India would provide financial aid to BPL families to help manage a child with major life-threatening diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rashtriya Arogya Nidhi

 

Provides financial assistance for medical treatment of poor patients with life-threatening diseases, especially children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana: This scheme was launched to reduce regional imbalances in tertiary healthcare services by setting up AIIMS-like institutions and upgrading medical colleges. It does not provide direct financial support to patients.

 

Option C. Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: This is a training program for healthcare workers, focusing on essential newborn care and resuscitation. It aims at reducing neonatal mortality, not financial assistance.

 

Option D. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram: A child health screening and early intervention service, addressing 4Ds—

 

  1. Defects at birth, 
  2. Deficiencies,
  3. Diseases, and 
  4. Developmental delays including disabilities. It provides screening and referral, not direct treatment funding.

questions.text: Supplementary nutrition for malnourished children under ICDS provides approx:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 800 kcal & 20–25 g protein

 

  • Severely malnourished children receive enhanced supplementation to promote catch-up growth.

 

Under ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services), children aged 6 months to 6 years receive supplementary nutrition to bridge the calorie-protein gap.

 

  • Normal children: ~500 kcal & 12–15 g protein/day
  • Malnourished (Severely underweight): ~800 kcal & 20–25 g protein/day

 

Thus, malnourished children are provided with higher caloric and protein supplementation to aid catch-up growth.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about health indicators:

  1. Number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on current rates of sickness and mortality-Sullivan index
  2. Simplest measure of burden of disease-Incidence
  3. Optimal utilisation of health services-Negative Bed turnover ratio
  4. Best indicator of effectiveness of health care-IMR
  5. Cost effectiveness of NHP-DALY
  6. Best measure of standard of living-HDI
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4, 6

 

  • IMR is the best indicator of effectiveness of health care services.
  • HDI is considered the best measure of standard of living.
  • Other options explained:
  • Sullivan index → Only Disability free LE 
  • Incidence as simplest burden measure → Proportional Mortality rate is considered as simplest measure of burden.
  • Negative bed turnover ratio for utilization →  It should be slightly positive 
  • DALY for NHP cost-effectiveness → QALY is used as measure

questions.text: In Home Based Newborn Care (HBNC), number of postnatal visits by ASHA after LSCS is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

In Home Based Newborn Care (HBNC), the number of postnatal visits by ASHA after a caesarean section (LSCS) delivery is:

 

A) 5 visits = Day 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 & 42.

 

  • "In cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, ASHAs are entitled to full incentive of Rs. 250 if she completes all five visits starting from Day 7 to Day 42."
  • ASHAs are entitled to conduct five postnatal visits starting from day 7 up to day 42 after a mother returns home post-LSCS (around 5-6 days after delivery).
  • This is different from
    •  6 visits in institutional normal deliveries [Day 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 & 42] 
    •  7 for home deliveries[ Day 0, 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 & 42]
  • The visits aim to monitor newborn health, detect illness early, and provide counselling and support to the mother.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department of an academic medical center with chest pain, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis. Investigators are designing a randomized control trial to test the hypothesis that drug B will decrease the mortality associated with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction compared to standard of care. To ensure that investigators will not miss a difference between drug B and standard of care (if a difference truly exists), which of the following would they want to maximize?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1- beta

 

Power = 1–β. It is the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when a true effect exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α: Type I error (false positive). Lowering α reduces false positives but does not raise power.

 

Option B. β: Type II error (false negative). We want to minimize, not maximize.

 

Option C. 1–alpha: Represents specificity, not power.

 

Type I Error (α) vs Type II Error (β)

choices.text: All vaccines up to 2 years of age
All vaccines by 5 years of age
All vaccines by 1 year of age

questions.text: A “Fully immunized child” refers to one who has received:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) All vaccines by 1 year of age

 

Defined as a child receiving BCG, 3 doses of DPT/OPV, and measles vaccine by 12 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All vaccines up to 2 years of age: Not as per UIP definition.

 

Option B. All vaccines by 5 years of age: Over-extended.

 

Option D. Only BCG, OPV, DPT: Incomplete

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought with complaints of persistent fever, and cough without sputum for 3 weeks. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest X ray 

 

he NTEP algorithm follows this sequence :

 

Chest X-ray first - Done upfront in all suspected TB cases

 

Based on CXR findings:

 

If highly suggestive of TB → Proceed to sputum/gastric aspiration for NAAT testing

 

If non-specific → Consider antibiotics trial first

 

If normal → Evaluate for extrapulmonary TB

questions.text:
Components evaluated in Sample Registration System (SRS):


1.Crude Birth Rate

2. Crude Death Rate
3. Infant Mortality Rate
4. Maternal Mortality Ratio
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

SRS provides reliable estimates of vital rates such as birth rate, death rate, infant mortality rate, and maternal mortality ratio at national and state levels through continuous enumeration and surveys. The system combines the advantages of both continuous (longitudinal) enumeration and survey procedures. All vital events occurring to usual residents of the sample area are recorded. SRS comes under Ministry of home affairs

questions.text: Which scheme was originally launched to address rural housing in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana – Gramin (PMAY-G)

 

Launched in 1985 under the Rural Development Ministry to provide housing for BPL families. It is supervised by Ministry of Rural Development. Indira Awaas Yojana is now called Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana – Gramin (PMAY-G) since April 2016.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana: This scheme targets unorganized labourers, providing social security benefits, skill training, and welfare support. It does not focus on housing, but rather on improving livelihoods and labour welfare.

 

Option B. Pradhan Mantri Kaushal Vikas Yojana (PMKVY): PMKVY is aimed at youth skill development by providing short-term training programs and certification for employability. 

 

Option C. Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana (RKVY): RKVY focuses on agriculture development, enhancing farm productivity and infrastructure. It provides funding for agricultural projects and irrigation.

choices.text: ART Centre → Link ART Centre → ART Plus Centre → Centre of Excellence
Centre of Excellence → ART Plus Centre → ART Centre → Link ART Centre
ART Plus Centre → Centre of Excellence → ART Centre → Link ART Centre
Link ART Centre → ART Centre → ART Plus Centre → Centre of Excellence

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the hierarchy of NACO ART centres from highest to lowest level according to their organisational structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Centre of Excellence → ART Plus Centre → ART Centre → Link ART Centre

 

  • CoE provides advanced HIV care and training; 
  • ART Plus manages second-line therapy; 
  • ART centres provide standard ART;
  • Link ART centres increase service accessibility.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ART Centre → Link ART Centre → ART Plus Centre → CoE → Reverse order.

 

Option C. ART Plus → CoE → ART Centre → Link → CoE is top, not below ART Plus.

 

Option D. Link → ART Centre → ART Plus → CoE → Wrong sequence, starts at lowest.

questions.text: Plasma homocysteine levels are measured in patients with acute coronary syndrome who are treated at a large community hospital. The mean plasma homocysteine level in this group is determined to be 11.1 μmol/L with a standard deviation of 1.2μmol/L. In a separate group of patients, the mean plasma level is 9.5μmol/L and the standard deviation is 1.3 μmol/L. Which of the following statistical methods should be used to compare the mean homocysteine levels of these 2 groups of patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Two-sample t test

 

A two-sample (independent) t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups when the data is continuous and approximately normally distributed. Here, plasma homocysteine levels are continuous variables measured in two separate patient groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Linear regression: Used to study the relationship between a dependent and one/more independent variables. Not appropriate when simply comparing means.

 

Option C. Correlation coefficient: Measures the strength and direction of association between two continuous variables in the same group, not between two separate groups.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: Used for categorical data (eg, proportions, frequencies), not continuous variables like plasma levels.

choices.text: It was started in 2010 for control of non-communicable diseases and monthly data reporting
Syndromic surveillance is conducted by medical officers, diagnosing based on history and examination
Conducts weekly surveillance reporting and focuses on epidemic-prone diseases
Laboratory surveillance is done by health workers using field surveys

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the following program is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conducts weekly surveillance reporting and focuses on epidemic-prone diseases

 

IDSP collects and reports data on epidemic-prone diseases on a weekly basis (Monday–Sunday) and aims to detect and respond to outbreaks quickly.

 

Other statements:

 

Option A. IDSP was started in November 2004. It does NOT focus primarily on non-communicable diseases or monthly data, but rather on acute communicable disease outbreaks.

 

Option B. Syndromic surveillance is indeed part of IDSP (diagnosed on the basis of history and examination), but it is conducted mainly by health workers, not only medical officers.

 

Option D. Laboratory surveillance is done through dedicated labs and staff, not health workers in the field.

questions.text: A researcher is comparing three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Friedman test

 

The Friedman test is a non-parametric alternative to repeated-measures ANOVA. It is particularly useful when comparing three or more related groups with ordinal or non-normally distributed data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t test: Compares means of two groups, assumes normal distribution. Not valid for three groups with non-parametric data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used to compare means among more than two groups but assumes normality and equal variances. Not applicable here.

 

Option D. Pearson: Refers to Pearson’s correlation coefficient, used to assess linear relationship between two continuous variables, not group comparisons.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of cyclopropagative biological transmission in vectors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodia in Anopheles

 

  • Malarial parasites undergo asexual multiplication (sporogony) and developmental transformation (gametocyte → sporozoite) within the female Anopheles mosquito. This makes it a classic example of cyclopropagative transmission.

 

Types of Transmission in Vectors

 

1. Propagative:

  • only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • Example: Plague bacilli in rat fleas, YF in Aedes

 

2. Cyclo-propagative:

  • The agent changes in both form and number.
  • Example: Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

 

3. Cyclo-developmental:

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • Example: Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

 

4. Transovarial:

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • Example: Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks, Mite in scrub typhus 

 

5. Transstadial:

 

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • Example: Borrelia burgdorferi, Indian tick typhus in ticks.

 

Malarial parasites undergo asexual multiplication (sporogony) and developmental transformation (gametocyte → sporozoite) within the female Anopheles mosquito. This makes it a classic example of cyclopropagative transmission.

questions.text: A study calculated the correlation coefficient between smoking and lung cancer incidence as 1.4. What does this result indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mistake in calculation

 

The correlation coefficient (r) cannot exceed +1 or be less than –1. A reported value of 1.4 suggests a statistical or computational error in the analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weak correlation: Weak correlation would mean r is closer to 0 (eg, 0.1–0.3).

 

Option B. Moderate correlation: Moderate correlation usually lies between 0.4–0.6.

 

Option C. Strong correlation: Strong correlation is seen when r is closer to +1 or –1, but still ≤1 in value.

choices.text: CV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
CV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.text: A study was conducted on two different samples for comparing variation between DBP and Vitamin D. The mean diastolic blood pressure is 110 mm Hg with standard deviation 11 and the mean vitamin D level is 18 with standard deviation 3. Which of the following statement is true regarding the coefficient of variation (CV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

 

  • CV of DBP = 11/110 ×100 = 10%. 
  • CV of Vitamin D = 3/18 ×100 = 16.7%. 

 

Hence, Vitamin D shows greater relative variability than DBP.

questions.text: RDA of calcium for pregnant and breastfeeding mothers are, respectively:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1000 mg and 1200 mg

 

  • Pregnant mothers require 1000 mg/day to support fetal bone development, while lactating mothers need 1200 mg/day to compensate for calcium lost in breast milk.

 

RDA of Calcium:

 

  • Males, Females and Pregnant ladies = 1000mg/day.
  • Lactating females, Elderly male & female [>60years] = 1200mg/day.

choices.text: Cattle should be housed within 25 metres of residential areas
Water source should be located at a distance greater than 500 metres
Window area should be at least 1/5th of floor area
More than two persons sharing a room must have less than 40 sq ft per person

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding standard housing criteria in community medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Window area should be at least 1/5th of floor area

 

Adequate ventilation requires windows to cover at least 20% of the floor area, ensuring proper airflow and natural light.

 

Other Options:

Option A. Cattle should be housed within 25 metres of residential areas: They should be kept at least 25 metres away, not within.

 

Option B. Water source should be located at a distance greater than 500 metres: Safe drinking water should be within 500 metres.

 

Option D. More than two persons sharing a room must have less than 40 sq ft per person: Standard requires ≥50 sq ft per person to avoid overcrowding.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of population norm:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Health assistant – 1/50000

 

The correct norm is 1 Health Assistant per 30,000 population in plain areas (20,000 in hilly/tribal areas). 1/50,000 is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nurse – 1/5000: Correct as per Indian Public Health Standards.

 

Option B. Pharmacist – 1/10,000: Correct norm.

 

Option D. Doctor – 1/1000: Correct WHO recommendation for doctor-population ratio.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements: 

  1. Influenza and pneumococcal vaccines are advocated in the elderly. 
  2. Strict isolation is advised for Measles, Varicella, Influenza, Nipah virus and CJD
  3. Applied Nutrition program supplying seeds and manure at village level is funded by UNICEF 
  4. Dixon’s Q test is primarily used to detect outliers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1: Influenza and pneumococcal vaccines are advocated in the elderly: Influenza and pneumococcal vaccination are recommended for elderly persons to prevent severe disease and complications; 

 

Statement 3: Applied Nutrition program supplying seeds and manure at village level is funded by UNICEF: Public health nutrition support programs (like seed/inputs at community level) have been supported by agencies including UNICEF in various settings; 

 

Statement 4: Dixon’s Q test is primarily used to detect outliers: Dixon’s Q-test is a classical statistical method specifically used to detect a single outlier in a small sample. Together these points (1,3,4) are correct.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2: Strict isolation is advised for Measles, Varicella, Influenza, Nipah virus and CJD: Strict isolation is required for measles/varicella/influenza to varying degrees (airborne/contact precautions), and Nipah requires strict isolation; CJD (Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease), however, is not managed by conventional infectious disease isolation — it requires special prion-handling precautions (instrument decontamination), so grouping CJD as “strict isolation” with the others is inappropriate.

questions.text:
According to NUHM, arrange the following in the correct order as per population covered from highest level to lowest. 

 

  1. Urban Primary Health Centre
  2. Urban Community Health Centre
  3. Auxiliary Nurse Midwife
  4. Urban Social Health Activist
  5. Mahila Arogya Samiti
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 3, 4, 5

 

2. Under NUHM (National Urban Health Mission) the Urban Community Health Centre (UCHC/UCHC-level) is the higher-level facility covering the largest population catchment. It is followed by

 

1. Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) which serves fewer people. 

 

3. Frontline workers like ANMs serve individual households and thus cover smaller populations than PHCs.

 

4. Urban Social Health Activists (USHA/ASHA-equivalent) 

 

5. Mahila Arogya Samitis work at the community/ward level covering still smaller populations.

 

Thus the ordering 2→1→3→4→5 reflects decreasing catchment size.

questions.text: Which among the following is considered the best method for removal of permanent hardness of water?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Permutit process

 

Permanent hardness (caused by dissolved chlorides and sulfates of calcium and magnesium) cannot be removed by boiling. The Permutit (ion-exchange) process (using zeolite/permutit columns) exchanges sodium for calcium/magnesium ions and effectively softens water permanently. It is the standard industrial/household method to treat permanent hardness when regeneration is feasible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Boiling: Removes temporary hardness (carbonate hardness) by precipitating bicarbonates as carbonate, but does not remove permanent hardness caused by non-carbonate salts.

 

Option B. Addition of lime (Ca(OH)₂): Lime softening can reduce some hardness (especially temporary and bicarbonate hardness) and precipitate some salts, but is less effective, bulky and not as convenient/complete as ion-exchange for permanent hardness.

 

Option C. Addition of sodium carbonate: Soda ash (sodium carbonate) can precipitate calcium as carbonate and remove some hardness — useful in water treatment, but Permutit (ion exchange) is superior for efficient, continuous removal of permanent hardness.

questions.text: During a study on the effect of smoking on life expectancy, the correlation coefficient was found to be 0.60. What is the coefficient of determination for this study?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 0.36

 

The coefficient of determination (R²) is obtained by squaring the correlation coefficient (r). Here, r = 0.60, so R² = 0.60 × 0.60 = 0.36. This means that 36% of the variation in life expectancy can be explained by smoking status, while the rest is due to other factors. It provides a better understanding of the strength of association in regression models.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.6: This represents the correlation coefficient itself, not the coefficient of determination. R (0.6) indicates moderate positive correlation, but it is not the correct answer to this question.

 

Option C. 0.4: This value has no statistical relevance here, as R² is strictly r × r. It is a distractor based on confusing correlation with regression slope.

 

Option D. 1.2: Coefficient of determination cannot exceed 1, as it is a proportion. Any value above 1 indicates a conceptual error in calculation.

choices.text: Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and night time
Aerobic during day time and night time

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Oxidation Pond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time

 

Oxidation ponds are shallow sewage treatment ponds where natural processes involving sunlight, algae, and bacteria treat wastewater. During the daytime, oxygen is produced by algal photosynthesis, making the pond aerobic. At night, photosynthesis ceases and oxygen is consumed by microorganisms, leading to anaerobic conditions. This cyclic variation is a hallmark of oxidation ponds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time: This is incorrect because sunlight is essential for algae to produce oxygen; hence, aerobic conditions are always linked to daytime, not nighttime.

 

Option C. Anaerobic during day time and night time: If this were true, the pond would resemble a septic tank, not an oxidation pond. It would fail to utilize algae-mediated oxygenation.

 

Option D. Aerobic during day time and night time: Continuous aerobic conditions are not possible since oxygen is not produced at night, making this option incorrect

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements?

 

  1. Rabies is an example of amphixenosis 
  2. A disease whose pathogenic response is higher in children compared in adults is defined as hyperendemic disease
  3. Most efficient to control urban malaria is environmental control of larva
  4. CBR ≈ (8×TFR) + 1
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

  • Environmental (larval) control — source reduction, filling, drainage, larviciding — is highly effective in urban malaria where breeding sites are identifiable and man-made. 
  • The rule-of-thumb relation CBR ≈ (8 × TFR) + 1 is a demographic approximation often used in population studies. 

 

Therefore statements 3 and 4 are correct in public health contexts.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Rabies is an example of amphixenosis: Rabies is classically a zoonosis (animal-to-human transmission). The term amphixenosis is uncommon and not correctly applied here; hence statement 1 is not correct.

 

2. A disease whose pathogenic response is higher in children compared in adults is defined as hyperendemic disease: Hyperendemic denotes persistently high incidence across age groups; the wording “pathogenic response higher in children” is inaccurate — that describes age-specific susceptibility rather than the definition of hyperendemic.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. The best method for a Pap smear fixation is air fixation.
  2. The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome in a fetus is when the mother is infected between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.
  3. Surveillance is the performance and analysis of routine measurements while monitoring is the continuous analysis of systematically collected data.
  4. 0.5-3 microns is the most dangerous size of particles for causing pneumoconiosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4

 

Here is the analysis of each statement:

 

  1. The best method for Pap smear fixation is fixation with ethanol. 
    • Generally, wet fixation immediately after smear preparation (using 95% ethyl alcohol) is considered the best and most reliable method for Pap smears. 
  2. Highest risk period for congenital varicella syndrome is 13-20 weeks of gestation. [CORRECT]
    • Highest risk period is the first 20 weeks, especially 8-20 weeks, including 13-20 weeks, for congenital varicella syndrome development.
  3. Surveillance is the performance and analysis of routine measurements while monitoring is the continuous analysis of systematically collected data. {INCORRECT}
    • Opposite is correct; monitoring is routine data collection and recording, while surveillance is a more intensive, analytical process aimed at decision-making.
  4. 0.5-3 microns is the most dangerous size of particles for pneumoconiosis. [CORRECT]
    • Particles of 0.5 to 3 microns are indeed most dangerous as they can reach the alveoli and cause lung diseases like pneumoconiosis

questions.text: A surveillance study is conducted to assess the long-term efficacy and safety of a drug currently being used to treat patients with heart failure. Researchers enroll 8,300 patients with heart failure. The patients receive the drug once daily for 6 months. The results show significant clinical improvement, but severe hypernatremia is observed in 23 patients. The study publication recommends a lower dose of the drug in patients with baseline normonatremia and hypokalemia to prevent hypernatremia. Which of the following best characterizes this type of study?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phase 4 clinical trial

 

Phase-4 (post-marketing) studies assess long-term safety, rare adverse events, and effectiveness in broad real-world populations after regulatory approval. A large cohort monitored in routine practice for new safety signals (e.g., 23 cases of severe hypernatremia) typifies Phase-4 surveillance and informs dose/safety recommendations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase 1 clinical trial: Small first-in-human trials focusing on safety/pharmacokinetics, not large post-marketing surveillance.

 

Option B. Phase 2 clinical trial: Early efficacy and dose-finding in patients but pre-approval and smaller scale than described.

 

Option C. Phase 3 clinical trial: Large randomized pre-approval trials for efficacy and safety; while large, they occur before marketing and are not the same as post-marketing surveillance.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important step in the secondary treatment of sewage in a sewage treatment plant (STP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aeration

 

Secondary treatment is biological oxidation of dissolved organics; aeration supplies oxygen to aerobic microbes in activated sludge or aeration basins, enabling microbial degradation of BOD and achieving the core objective of secondary treatment. Effective aeration determines treatment efficiency and effluent quality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening: Primary mechanical pretreatment to remove large debris — necessary but not the biological heart of secondary treatment.

 

Option B. Grit chamber: Removes heavy inorganic grit to protect equipment — also a primary pretreatment step.

 

Option D. Sludge digestion: Stabilizes biosolids (anaerobic digestion) and is a tertiary/solids-handling process, not the main secondary oxidation step.

choices.text: Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC) is used to represent the germicidal power of a disinfectant.
For workrooms with exposure to contaminants, the minimum recommended number of air changes per hour is 4-6 to maintain air quality and protect worker health.
Demographic trap is seen in Stage 2 of demographic cycle.
Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management is ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management is ministry of Health and Family Welfare

 

This statement is incorrect because the nodal authority for disaster management in India is the Ministry of Home Affairs (through NDMA/SDMA structures). Health ministry plays a crucial response role (medical relief, public health) but is not the central nodal ministry for overall disaster management coordination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC) is used to represent the germicidal power of a disinfectant: Historically, Ridel-Walker/phenol coefficients were used to compare germicidal efficacy under specified conditions; although dated, the statement about its use is essentially correct in principle.

 

Option B. For workrooms with exposure to contaminants, the minimum recommended number of air changes per hour is 4-6 to maintain air quality and protect worker health: For general workrooms with low-to-moderate contaminant levels, a guideline of ~4–6 air changes/hour is commonly recommended to maintain acceptable air quality and dilution ventilation.

 

Option C. Demographic trap is seen in Stage 2 of demographic cycle: The demographic trap (rapid population growth due to falling mortality while fertility remains high) corresponds to the transitional stages (commonly Stage 2), so statement C is acceptable.

questions.text: Which of the following solid waste disposal methods is characterized by layering municipal garbage with night soil, dung, and earth to undergo anaerobic digestion over time?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bangalore method

 

The Bangalore method is a traditional composting/biological digestion approach where refuse is layered with night soil, dung and earth to facilitate anaerobic decomposition and volume reduction; it was used historically for small-scale municipal waste stabilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Landfill: Engineered deposition with compaction and covering; not specifically the layering-with-night-soil anaerobic composting technique.

 

Option B. Incineration: Thermal destruction of waste at high temperatures — a combustion method, not biological layering.

 

Option C. Pulverization: Mechanical size reduction of waste material, not a waste stabilization/disposal technology relying on anaerobic digestion.

choices.text: Knowledge and skills instilled in the minds

questions.text: All of the following apply to health propaganda except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reflective behavior is promoted

 

Propaganda is designed to persuade and often targets emotions and attitudes using selective information; it focuses on dissemination and persuasive messaging rather than fostering critical, reflective decision-making. Therefore promoting reflective (critical) behavior is not a typical aim of propaganda.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knowledge and skills instilled in the minds: Propaganda may convey knowledge or instructions, but often in a biased manner; it can instill actionable skills if designed that way.

 

Option C. Appeals to emotion: A hallmark of propaganda is emotional appeal to influence attitudes and behaviour quickly.

 

Option D. Process is information centered: Propaganda often centres on targeted information (though selective), which drives its messaging strategy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to express the strength of sewage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. Coli Count

 

“Sewage strength” generally refers to organic and solids load affecting treatment — measured by BOD, COD, and suspended solids — which determine treatment design and oxygen demand. E. coli count reflects fecal contamination/health hazard but is not a measure of organic strength for engineering purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suspended particles: Suspended solids are a primary parameter indicating particulate load and affect settling and treatment.

 

Option C. COD (Chemical Oxygen Demand): COD quantifies oxygen equivalents for organic/inorganic oxidizable matter — central to sewage strength assessment.

 

Option D. BOD (Biochemical Oxygen Demand): BOD is the classic operational parameter measuring biodegradable organic load and is essential for defining sewage strength.

questions.text: Under the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), NGO eye hospitals are classified as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary level centres

 

Under NPCBVI, many NGO eye hospitals that provide comprehensive clinical services, routine ocular surgeries (including cataract with IOL), and outreach/referral support are designated as secondary level centres — they function as district/subdistrict surgical units delivering definitive eye care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary level centres: Vision centres and basic screening units — limited to primary eye care; NGO surgical hospitals exceed this scope.

 

Option C. Tertiary level centres: Provide subspecialty services (retina, complex glaucoma) and training; only select NGO hospitals qualify as tertiary.

 

Option D. Intermediate level centres: Not a standard NPCBVI designation; secondary is the commonly used classification for district surgical units.

questions.text: You are conducting a survey to investigate the prevalence of hypertension in a community. The data collected from individuals shows an association between obesity, decreased physical activity, and hypertension. Which of the following best describes this type of study?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross-sectional study

 

A cross-sectional study collects exposure and outcome data simultaneously at a single point in time across individuals, making it ideal to estimate prevalence and associations (e.g., obesity and hypertension) in a community survey; it does not establish temporal sequence or causality.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: Uses group-level aggregate data (not individual-level) and is subject to ecological fallacy; not matching the described individual-level associations.

 

Option B. Case series: Descriptive list of cases without a comparison group — unsuitable for measuring association in a population.

 

Option D. Cohort study: Prospective/retrospective follow-up assessing incidence and temporality — more resource-intensive and not the cross-sectional snapshot described.

questions.text: A research laboratory develops a new serologic test for detecting prostate cancer. The new assay is compared to biopsy. It is found that the test result is negative in 95% of patients who do not have the disease. If the new assay is used on 8 blood samples taken from patients without prostate cancer, what is the probability of all 8 test results coming back negative?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.958 (raised to power 8)

 

If specificity = 95% (probability of a negative result in disease-free individuals = 0.95), then the probability that all 8 independent disease-free samples test negative is the product 0.95×0.95×⋯[8 times]= 0.95^8

 

This follows from independence and multiplicative rule for probabilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.05 × 8: Incorrect — confuses false positive probability and linear summation; probabilities are not summed this way for joint events.

 

Option B. 0.95 × 8: Invalid operation — probability × count is not meaningful and may exceed 1.

 

Option C. 0.05 (raised to power 8): Would be probability all 8 are false positives (if false positive rate = 0.05), not the probability of all negative results.

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Many children from a particular community coming to a hospital were detected to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control study has to be done to find whether the chemical and ALL are associated, what will be taken as the control?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease

 

Controls in a case–control study should represent the source population that produced the cases and should be at risk of becoming cases; selecting children without ALL from the same OPD (or same community) ensures comparability of exposure opportunity and reduces selection bias, making them appropriate controls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease: Choosing only exposed non-cases biases the exposure distribution in controls (overrepresentation of exposure) and invalidates comparisons.

 

Option B. Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease: These are cases (affected) from a different exposure stratum — not controls.

 

Option D. All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status: That’s the case group itself; controls must be disease-free.

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d 

 

  • 1-b. Walter Reed – Yellow fever: He proved that yellow fever is transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, a landmark in tropical medicine.
  • 2-c. Edward Jenner – Smallpox vaccination: Introduced cowpox inoculation as a preventive method against smallpox, laying the foundation of modern immunization.
  • 3-a. James Lind – Prevention of scurvy by citrus fruits: Conducted the first clinical trial in sailors, showing that citrus fruits prevented scurvy.
  • 4-d. Ronald Ross – Malaria caused by Anopheles: Discovered the role of Anopheles mosquitoes in the transmission of malaria, winning the Nobel Prize.

questions.text: According to a study, pure vegetarians had a lower incidence of colon cancer than non-vegetarians, and this led researchers to the conclusion that beta-carotene is protective against cancer. This may not be the case since vegetarian subjects may be eating a high-fiber diet that lowers their risk of developing cancer. This is an illustration of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Confounding factor


A confounding factor occurs when the observed association between an exposure and an outcome is influenced by a third variable. Here, beta-carotene intake was thought to reduce colon cancer, but the protective effect may actually be due to higher fiber intake in vegetarians, which confounds the observed association. Note the difference between confounding factor and effect modifier which appear similar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multifactorial causation: Suggests that multiple factors act together to cause a disease (e.g., genetic + environmental), but here the issue is misattributing causation, not multiple causes.

 

Option B. Causal association: Implies a direct cause-effect link, but in this study the link between beta-carotene and cancer risk is not directly causal.

 

Option D. Common association: Refers to two variables being associated due to chance or background conditions, but this does not explain the distortion due to a third variable like fiber.

choices.text: Any of these can be taken
Ask the patient to delay the travel plan, as both vaccines need at least 4 weeks for conferring protection

questions.text: 25 year old A patient who is set to travel to a typhoid endemic region in 10 days seeks your advice on vaccination. What should you recommend?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vi Polysaccharide vaccine
 

The Vi polysaccharide injectable vaccine provides protection within 7–10 days, making it suitable for travelers with short notice before departure. It is safe, effective, and can be administered as a single dose in adults and children above 2 years of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ty21a Vaccine: This is an oral live-attenuated vaccine requiring multiple doses over a week and at least 2 weeks for full protection, hence not ideal with only 10 days before travel.

 

Option C. Any of these can be taken: Incorrect, as the Ty21a vaccine will not provide full protection in time. The choice must be specific based on time available.

 

Option D. Ask the patient to delay the travel plan, as both vaccines need at least 4 weeks for conferring protection: Not practical advice here, since the injectable Vi vaccine can indeed provide adequate protection within the available 10-day window.

questions.text:
Arrange the following disaster management steps in the correct sequential order:

A) Response
B) Preparedness
C) Recovery
D) Mitigation
E) Prevention
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E, D, B, A, C

 

The correct sequence of disaster management steps is:

 

E) Prevention,

D) Mitigation,

B) Preparedness,

A) Response,

C) Recovery

 

Explanation of the Sequence:

 

  1. Prevention: Actions taken to avoid the occurrence of a disaster.
  2. Mitigation: Measures to reduce the severity or impact of a disaster if it occurs.
  3. Preparedness: Planning and training to effectively respond to disasters.
  4. Response: Actions taken immediately before, during, and after a disaster to save lives and reduce damage.
  5. Recovery: Activities to restore normalcy and rebuild after the disaster.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the frequency of polycythemia in a population of a remote, mountainous region. A representative sample of 100 men shows a normal distribution of hemoglobin concentration with a mean concentration of 17g/dl and a standard error of 0.1 g/dl.  Which of the following best represents the probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 16%

 

The mean is 17 g/dL, SE = 0.1. A value of 18 g/dL is 10 standard errors above the mean (1 g/dL ÷ 0.1). From normal distribution, a difference of 1 g/dL corresponds to a z-score of 10. However, the question is framed for SD context (commonly tested): 1 SD above the mean corresponds to ~16% probability in the tail, hence 16% is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most peripheral centre under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Designated Microscopy Centre

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) is the most peripheral unit under RNTCP. It is located at the sub-district level and provides sputum smear microscopy services for diagnosis and follow-up of TB patients. It serves as the first point of diagnostic contact in the hierarchy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: Functions at the district level and supervises TB control activities, but it is not peripheral—it is administrative.

 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory: Located at the state/regional level, mainly involved in culture, drug sensitivity testing, and quality control, far from the peripheral structure.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit: Supervises several DMCs (covering about 5 lakh population) but still above them in the hierarchy.

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pareto plot

 

The image provided is a Pareto plot.

 

  • Features: The chart presents failure types on the x-axis, the number of occurrences on the left y-axis, and cumulative percentage on the right y-axis. The failures are sorted so that the most frequent problems appear first, with a line tracking their cumulative impact, which is characteristic of a Pareto plot.
  • Purpose: Pareto plots are used to identify and prioritize the most significant factors in a process (the "vital few"), following the 80/20 rule.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ishikawa chart (also known as fishbone diagram) is used for root cause analysis.

 

Option B. Funnel plot is used in meta-analysis to check for publication bias.

 

Option D. Delphi plot is not a standard statistical plot type. Delphi method is based on the principle that forecasts (or decisions) from a structured group of individuals are more accurate than those from unstructured groups

choices.text: Periodic Deworming for children aged 1–19 years
Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) Campaign
To rule out thallasemia in all anemic patients using HPLC
Testing and Treatment of Anaemia using digital hemoglobinometers

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the six key interventions under the Anaemia Mukt Bharat strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To rule out thallasemia in all anemic patients using HPLC
