The Anaemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy focuses on population-level preventive and curative interventions — iron-folic acid supplementation, dietary counselling and BCC, deworming, screening with point-of-care Hb testing and treatment, etc. Routine universal HPLC testing to rule out thalassaemia for all anemic patients is not one of the core six programme interventions (it’s a targeted diagnostic approach, not a mass intervention).

 

Six interventions:

 

  1. Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation: 
  2. Deworming: 
  3. Intensified behavior change communication (BCC) campaigns
  4. Testing and treating anemia: 
  5. Mandatory provision of fortified foods
  6. Addressing non-nutritional causes: 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periodic deworming of children aged 1–19 years is explicitly part of AMB to reduce intestinal blood loss and improve Hb.

 

Option B. Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) Campaign: Year-round BCC to improve dietary practices, IFA compliance and sanitation is a pillar of AMB.

 

Option D. Testing and Treatment of Anaemia using digital hemoglobinometers: Use of digital hemoglobinometers for screening and test-and-treat algorithms is a key operational component of the program.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of steps in a randomized controlled trial?

  1. Blinding 
  2. Randomization
  3. Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria
  4. Statistical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CBAD

 

The logical sequence in designing & conducting an RCT begins with

 

  • Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria (C) to select eligible participants, F/B
  • Randomization (B) to allocate participants to arms, F/B
  • Blinding (A) if applicable to reduce bias, and finally
  • Statistical analysis (D) after data collection. 

 

Hence the order C → B → A → D is correct.

choices.text: 25 X 25 goal includes reducing prevalence of hypertension by 25%
Provides medication for 60 days to all beneficiaries
Use of “Simple App” for real-time BP monitoring

questions.text: All of the following are components of IHCI (India Hypertension Control Initiative) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Provides medication for 60 days to all beneficiaries
 

Under IHCI, free supply of antihypertensive drugs is ensured at public health facilities, but there is no universal provision of 60-day medication for all beneficiaries. Instead, drug availability depends on state procurement and facility logistics. Thus, this statement is not a true component of IHCI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Availability of recommended protocol drugs: Correct. IHCI emphasizes availability of protocol-based, effective, low-cost antihypertensives at all levels of healthcare.

 

Option B. 25 X 25 goal includes reducing prevalence of hypertension by 25%: Correct. The 25 × 25 goal (set by WHO) includes reducing hypertension prevalence by 25% by 2025, which is integrated into IHCI.

 

Option D. Use of “Simple App” for real-time BP monitoring: Correct. The “Simple App” is a digital tool for real-time monitoring of blood pressure and treatment adherence, a key innovation of IHCI.

choices.text: The ministry of health and family welfare has sponsored this program
Dressing materials and ulcer kits are provided
Amount of 8000 monthly is provided to all leprosy patients from BPL families
The district unit will supply the microcellular footwear

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes to the primary health centre with multiple cuts and abrasions on his feet. He reports having reduced sensation in his feet. Which of the following is incorrect regarding govt. incentives for him?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amount of 8000 monthly is provided to all leprosy patients from BPL families

 

Government leprosy programs provide medical treatment, ulcer care kits, rehabilitation support and disability prevention (including microcellular footwear via district units) and are run under the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare/NLEP. However, a blanket monthly cash payment of ₹8000 to all BPL leprosy patients is not a standard universal govt incentive; cash assistance schemes are specific, limited, and not uniformly ₹8000/month for all.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  The ministry of health and family welfare has sponsored this program: The National Leprosy Eradication Programme is implemented under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare — this is correct.

 

Option B. Dressing materials and ulcer kits are provided: Provision of dressing materials and ulcer care kits for neuropathic ulcers is an established part of leprosy care packages.

 

Option D. The district unit will supply the microcellular footwear: District leprosy units commonly arrange preventive footwear (microcellular footwear) distribution for neuropathic patients — this is part of rehabilitation services.

choices.text: Inhibits the formation of intracellular viral forms of orthopoxviruses..
Targets the viral p37 protein, preventing viral envelopment and systemic spread.
Suppresses the replication of the variola virus within the host cell.
Inhibits viral entry into host cells by blocking the viral fusion protein

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with monkeypox and is started on tecovirimat for treatment. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of tecovirimat?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Targets the viral p37 protein, preventing viral envelopment and systemic spread.

 

Tecovirimat (ST-246) specifically targets the orthopoxvirus p37 (F13L) envelope protein, disrupting viral envelopment and formation of extracellular enveloped virus, thereby preventing systemic spread of virus particles. This targeted mechanism reduces viral dissemination and is why tecovirimat is effective against orthopoxviruses (including monkeypox).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits the formation of intracellular viral forms of orthopoxviruses: Blocking intracellular viral forms is vague and not the precise mechanism; tecovirimat acts on viral envelopment rather than generic intracellular formation.

 

Option C. Suppresses the replication of the variola virus within the host cell: “Suppresses replication” is nonspecific — tecovirimat does not directly inhibit genome replication enzymes but hinders envelopment and egress.

 

Option D. Inhibits viral entry into host cells by blocking the viral fusion protein: Inhibiting viral entry/fusion is the mechanism of some antivirals/monoclonals, but tecovirimat acts post-replication on envelopment, not fusion/entry.

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement for minimum 250 days in a year
2/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement for minimum 200 days in a year
½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement for minimum 200 days in a year
½ of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of total energy requirement for minimum 250 days in a year

questions.text: Given the constraints and the need to ensure minimal nutritional adequacy, what should the minimum supplementation be in the Mid-Day Meal to support the children's needs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1/2 of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement for minimum 200 days in a year

 

National school feeding programs aim to provide a substantial fraction of a child’s daily nutrient needs within operational constraints. The widely accepted operational minimum is to cover at least one-third of daily energy needs and a significant portion of protein; programs generally guarantee feeding for a minimum of ~200 school days per year. Option C best matches the practical compromise (200 days and 1/3 energy coverage) while ensuring higher protein proportion to support growth.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

  1. Emporiatrics is a term used to describe practice of traditional medicine in rural areas, often using herbal remedies and ancient healing techniques.
  2. Bland-Altmann test is used to compare a test with the gold standard.
  3. According to WHO, the safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is Beta activity 1Bq /L
  4. Congenital glaucoma is not covered under RBSK screening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

The Bland–Altman method assesses agreement between two quantitative measurement techniques (e.g., a test and a gold standard) and is widely used for method-comparison studies. WHO has set provisional screening/reference values for gross beta activity ~1 Bq/L in drinking water in some guidance documents. RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram) typically screens for a set of neonatal/child conditions; congenital glaucoma is not routinely included in the standard RBSK screening list — therefore statements 2, 3 and 4 are correct.

 

Other Option:

 

  • 1 (Emporiatrics): The term emporiatrics actually refers to travel medicine (health of travelers), not traditional rural herbal practice; thus statement 1 is incorrect.

questions.text: A study assessed the association between a new vaccine and traveler's diarrhea (TD). Researchers selected a random sample of people who intended to travel to regions where they were at increased risk for TD and who had received the new vaccine and another independent random sample of people who intended to travel to the same regions and who had not received the new vaccine. These 2 samples of travelers were assessed for the occurrence of TD during the trip and for 7 days after returning home. What is the study design?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prospective cohort

 

This design selects exposed (vaccinated) and unexposed (unvaccinated) individuals before outcome occurrence and follows them forward in time to measure incidence of traveler’s diarrhea — this is the definition of a prospective cohort study. The investigator is assessing incident outcomes among predefined exposure groups prospectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrospective cohort: Would select based on past exposure and use existing data to determine outcomes; here selection is prospective and followed forward.

 

Option C. Case-control: Starts with cases and controls and looks backward for exposures — not the described prospective sampling.

 

Option D. RCT: Would involve random allocation to vaccine vs placebo; here vaccine status is observational, not randomized.

questions.text: All of the following are direct modes of transmission except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fomite-borne transmission

 

Direct transmission involves person-to-person spread by direct contact, droplet spray or vertical mother-to-child transfer. Fomite-borne transmission is indirect — the pathogen transmits via contaminated inanimate objects (fomites), which is not direct person-to-person contact. Hence C is the exception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Droplet infection: Respiratory droplets directly infect mucosa of another person — a direct mode.

 

Option B. Vertical transmission: Transmission across the placenta/peripartum is direct mother-to-child transmission.

 

Option D. Contact with soil: While environmental, “contact with soil” can be direct environmental exposure (e.g., tetanus via direct inoculation) — considered direct exposure in many classification schemes — but not an indirect fomite route like C.

questions.text:
Match the following research institutes with their corresponding locations:

Column A

  1. National JALMA Institute for Leprosy
  2. National Institute of Occupational Health (NIOH)
  3. National Institute of Epidemiology
  4. National AIDS Research Institute (NARI)

 

Column B

  1. Pune
  2. Ahmedabad
  3. Agra
  4. Chennai
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-3, b-2, c-4, d-1


(i.e., 

 

  • JALMA — Agra;
  • NIOH — Ahmedabad; 
  • NIE — Chennai;
  • NARI — Pune)

 

These national institutes are located as mentioned above. This matching is standard administrative location knowledge.

questions.text: Which of the following is a WHO-recommended criterion for drinking water quality?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead <0.01 mg/dl

 

According to WHO guidelines for drinking water quality, the safe limits are:

 

  • Lead: <0.01 mg/L (since even low levels can cause neurotoxicity in children and hypertension in adults).
  • Arsenic: <0.01 mg/L (long-term exposure causes skin lesions and cancers).
  • Nitrates: <50 mg/L (to prevent methemoglobinemia in infants).
  • Nitrites: <0.2 mg/L.
  • Turbidity: should be <5 NTU to ensure effective disinfection.

questions.text: Which of the following methods would be most suitable for removing microbial contaminants by chemical coagulation and sedimentation from a water body?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rapid sand filter

 

Chemical coagulation (e.g., alum) and flocculation are followed by sedimentation to remove aggregated particles; subsequent rapid sand filtration polishes the effluent, removing remaining suspended flocs and microbes efficiently at a high flow rate. Rapid sand filters are commonly integrated with coagulation-sedimentation in conventional treatment plants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. (Super chlorination): A disinfection measure to kill microbes chemically, not a coagulation-sedimentation removal process.

 

Option C. (Slow sand filter): Effective for microbial removal by biological action but operates slowly and typically requires pre-treated (settled) water; used where simple treatment is required, but not the classic coagulation-sedimentation → rapid sand filter sequence.

 

Option D. (RO filter): Reverse osmosis removes dissolved contaminants by membrane filtration, high energy and cost — not the standard step after coagulation/sedimentation for municipal treatment.

questions.text: A new estrogen receptor agonist is being evaluated for the treatment of postmenopausal symptoms. A prospective study shows that the drug increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in treated women who smoke compared to untreated women who smoke, with a relative risk(RR) of 1.70 and p-value of 0.01. In nonsmokers, no increased risk of DVT is evident with use of the drug (RR = 0.96; p-value = 0.68). Which of the following describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Effect modification

 

This is an example of effect modification (interaction) — the effect of the exposure (estrogen agonist) on the outcome (DVT) varies by levels of another factor (smoking). The association is present in smokers but not in nonsmokers, indicating smoking modifies the drug’s effect rather than being a confounder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. (Confounding): Confounding is a third variable associated with both exposure and outcome that distorts effect estimates; here the differing effect sizes across strata indicate interaction rather than confounding.

 

Option C. (Lead time bias): Related to screening and apparent survival benefit, irrelevant to interaction between exposure and risk factors.

 

Option D. (Observer bias): Systematic measurement bias by the observer; not described by differential RR across subgroups.

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash
From onset of rash to 5 days after rash
From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

questions.text: In a busy OPD at a District hospital, you are evaluating a 5-year-old boy who presents with fever, generalized malaise, and a distinctive rash. The child's clinical presentation strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. The mother, anxious about the contagious nature of the disease and the risk it poses to her other kids and family members, inquires about the recommended period of isolation for her infected child. What would be your most appropriate recommendation for the duration of isolation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

 

Measles is contagious from the catarrhal (prodromal) stage (a few days before rash) until about 4 days after rash onset. Isolation should begin with prodromal symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and continue through the early post-rash infectious period (≈4 days) to prevent transmission.

questions.text: A child with a known allergy to neomycin is brought to a vaccination camp. Which vaccine is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella

 

Varicella vaccine formulations contain neomycin as a trace preservative; a documented severe allergy to neomycin is a contraindication to receiving varicella vaccine due to risk of anaphylactic reactions. Therefore varicella should be avoided in those with known neomycin allergy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR): Generally does not contain neomycin as a component that contraindicates vaccination; MMR may have minimal traces in some formulations but is usually considered safe—check manufacturer specifics.

 

Option B. Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV): Inactivated polio vaccine typically does not contain neomycin; it is not routinely contraindicated for neomycin allergy.

 

Option C. Japanese Encephalitis (JE): Most JE vaccine formulations do not contain neomycin as a component; check product leaflet, but varicella is the classic contraindicated vaccine for neomycin allergy

questions.text: Based on the graphical representation provided, which of the following equations corresponds to the regression model of the plotted graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) y=11+2x

 

Analysis

 

The graph shows data points at approximately:

 

  • (0, 12.5)
  • (1, 13)
  • (2, 15)
  • (4, 19)
  • (6, 23)

 

By inferring the co-ordinates, it can be seen that Y variable is much more than X variable. Therefore looking at Options, by trial and error, Option C should be verified first as it has Y variable much more than X variable

Verification of Option C

 

Testing the equation y = 11 + 2x:

 

  • At x = 1: y = 11 + 2(1) = 13 ✓ (exact match)
  • At x = 2: y = 11 + 2(2) = 15 ✓ (exact match)
  • At x = 4: y = 11 + 2(4) = 19 ✓ (exact match)
  • At x = 6: y = 11 + 2(6) = 23 ✓ (exact match)

choices.text: Having a population density of 390 persons per square km
At least half of adult males engaged in non-agricultural work

questions.text: Which of the following statements about criteria for an urban area in India is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least half of adult males engaged in Non-Agricultural work

 

Incorrect because at least 75% (not half) of male main workers engaged in non-agricultural work.

 

Other Options:

 

The Census of India defines an urban area as one that meets these conditions:

 

Option A. Having 5,000 or more inhabitants: Minimum population of 5,000.

 

Option B. Having a population density of 390 persons per square km: Population density of at least 400 [close to 390] persons per sq km

 

Option D. Having pronounced urban features: Having pronounced urban features is sometimes used .

questions.text: You are involved in a study about various types of diseases. Which of the following is an example of a Trans-stadial transmission?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indian tick typhus

 

In trans-stadial transmission, the pathogen is carried by the vector across different life stages (larva → nymph → adult). Rickettsia of Indian tick typhus persists in ticks through their developmental stages, making this a classic example.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plague: Is transmitted by flea bites through regurgitation mechanism, not by trans-stadial passage.

 

Option B. Taeniasis: Is caused by ingestion of larval cysts of Taenia from undercooked pork or beef, not via arthropod vectors.

 

Option C. Rabies: Is spread through saliva of infected animals via bites, not via vectors or their developmental stages.

questions.text: All of the following are health care delivery indicators, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bed turnover ratio


Bed turnover ratio is an indicator of hospital utilization, showing how many times a bed is used in a given period. It does not reflect the delivery system structure in the community, hence excluded from health care delivery indicators.

 

Few examples of Health Care Delivery Indicators:

 

  • Population per doctor → Indicates availability of medical doctors.
  • Population per nurse → Reflects adequacy of nursing manpower.
  • Population per dentist → Assesses oral health service coverage.
  • Population per trained birth attendant (TBA)/midwife → Tracks maternal and child health services.
  • Population per health worker (like ASHA/ANM) → Shows access to primary health care.
  • Population per bed ratio → Measures hospital/bed capacity in relation to population.
  • Doctor–nurse ratio → Helps evaluate balance of skilled manpower in health care delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Population per trained birth attendant: Measures the availability of skilled delivery services and is a delivery indicator.

 

Option B. Population-bed ratio: Reflects infrastructure availability in a health system, making it a delivery indicator.

 

Option D. Doctor-nurse ratio: Shows the balance of human resources within the health delivery structure, hence relevant.

questions.text: A clinical study examines the usefulness of 5 different biomarkers to detect Barrett esophagus, the only known precursor lesion of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Researchers evaluate the performance of each biomarker and report the sensitivity, specificity, and area under the curve (AUC) estimates. Which is the most accurate biomarker?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3


Biomarker 3 shows the highest AUC (0.879), which is the best indicator of diagnostic accuracy. It balances high sensitivity (70.8%) and very high specificity (91.7%), making it the most reliable among the five tested biomarkers for Barrett oesophagus detection.

questions.text: The Stanford Three-Community Study, the North Karelia Project, and the Lipid Research Clinics Study are well-known research efforts. What type of study design best describes these efforts?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Risk factor intervention trials


These landmark studies focused on community-based interventions targeting risk factors such as smoking, diet, and cholesterol to prevent cardiovascular diseases. They involved planned strategies, implementation, and evaluation of health outcomes, making them classic examples of risk factor intervention trials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort studies: follow exposed vs unexposed groups over time, but they don’t implement interventions.

 

Option B. Nested case-control studies: are performed within a cohort to compare cases and controls but are observational, not interventional.

 

Option C. Case series report studies: describe outcomes in small patient groups without controls or interventions, unsuitable here.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. FORD foundation is aiding in building toilets in India 
  2. Normalcy of data can be measured by histogram, box-whisker plot and Shapiro-Wilk test 
  3. Haddon matrix is a tool for prevention of injuries using epidemiology. 
  4. The Reston ebolavirus is most pathogenic in humans.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3
 

Statement 1. FORD foundation is aiding in building toilets in India: Ford Foundation has supported sanitation and development initiatives including toilet construction in India. 

 

Statement 2. Normalcy of data can be measured by histogram, box-whisker plot and Shapiro-Wilk test: Data normality is indeed assessed using graphical methods (histogram, box-plot) and statistical tests like Shapiro-Wilk. 

 

Statement 3. Haddon matrix is a tool for prevention of injuries using epidemiology: Haddon matrix applies epidemiologic principles to analyze host, agent, and environment factors in injuries for prevention strategies.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4. The Reston ebolavirus is most pathogenic in humans: Wrong, because Reston ebolavirus is considered non-pathogenic to humans, as there have been no reported human cases of illness from infection, despite the virus being known to cause a severe, lethal disease in non-human primates.

questions.text: The instrument shown is used to measure:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humidity

 

The instrument shown in the image is a hygrometer (specifically, a psychrometer), which is used to measure humidity in the air.

 

  • Function: A psychrometer consists of two thermometers (a dry bulb and a wet bulb). The difference in their readings allows for calculation of relative humidity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air velocity: Is measured by anemometers.

 

Option C. Radiant heat: Is measured by globe thermometers.

 

Option D. Air pollution index: Is measured using air quality monitors.

choices.text: Technique A is superior to Technique B
Technique B is superior to Technique A
The techniques should not be used in a clinical care setting

questions.text: Researchers at an academic trauma center conducted a randomized clinical trial comparing 2 surgical techniques (Technique A and Technique B) for repairing a mandible fracture. They examined rates of infectious complications and rates of malocclusion. A total of 100 patients were enrolled in the study. Results showed that the relative rate of infection with Technique A compared with Technique B was 0.86 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.57-1.28. What is a correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neither surgery technique is superior

 

Since the confidence interval (0.57–1.28) includes 1, there is no statistically significant difference between the two techniques. Hence, neither can be considered superior in terms of reducing infection or complications, and both remain acceptable for use in clinical care.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to assess the nutritional status of the children in a particular district. For this purpose, 2 children are randomly selected from every school in the district. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cluster

 

Schools act as clusters, and children are sampled within them. This reduces cost and logistics in large populations and is a standard method for community health surveys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random: requires selecting children directly from the whole district, not grouped by schools.

 

Option B. Systematic random: involves fixed intervals (e.g., every 5th child), not cluster-based.

 

Option C. Stratified random: divides population into strata (e.g., age or gender groups) before random selection, unlike clustering by schools.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would not be managed through mass drug administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A deficiency
 

Vitamin A deficiency is managed through periodic supplementation (prophylaxis), not mass drug administration. MDA is reserved for diseases with high transmission potential that can be interrupted through population-wide treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Worm infestations (soil-transmitted helminths): Are targeted in MDA using albendazole/mebendazole.

 

Option C. Scabies: Control in high-prevalence communities may use MDA with ivermectin.

 

Option D. Filariasis: Is controlled by annual MDA with DEC + albendazole (sometimes ivermectin).
